statement.text: Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque from the carotid bifurcation to prevent stroke. It is the gold standard for symptomatic carotid stenosis ≥50% and asymptomatic stenosis ≥60-70% in appropriate patients. The procedure involves arteriotomy, plaque removal, and patch closure, with neurological monitoring.
statement.formal: CEA: Surgical plaque removal from carotid bifurcation; Indications: symptomatic ≥50% (periop risk <6%), asymptomatic ≥60-70% (periop risk <3%); Technique: arteriotomy, endarterectomy, patch closure

explanation.intuition: CEA is like opening a clogged pipe and scraping out the deposits. We make an incision in the carotid artery, carefully remove the plaque that's blocking and breaking off into the brain, and then repair the artery, usually with a patch to make it wider than before. It's like cleaning out a drain and leaving it larger to prevent future clogs.
explanation.key_insight: CEA has been proven to prevent stroke in landmark trials (NASCET, ACAS), but benefit depends on low perioperative risk. If the surgery causes too many strokes itself, the benefit is negated. Quality metrics demand <6% perioperative stroke/death for symptomatic and <3% for asymptomatic patients.
explanation.technical_details: Standard CEA: longitudinal arteriotomy from CCA across bifurcation into ICA, develop endarterectomy plane in media, remove plaque in one piece, tack distal intima if needed, patch closure (bovine pericardium, Dacron, or vein). Eversion CEA: transect ICA, evert and remove plaque, reimplant - no patch needed. Shunting (Javid, Pruitt) used if cerebral perfusion inadequate during cross-clamp.

eversion_cea.approach: Transection of ICA at origin, eversion of plaque

indications.symptomatic_70_99: Class I - clear benefit, NNT=6 at 2 years
indications.symptomatic_50_69: Class IIa - moderate benefit, select patients
indications.asymptomatic_60_70: Class IIa if periop risk <3% and life expectancy >5 years

preoperative.imaging: Duplex ultrasound (first-line), CTA or MRA for confirmation/planning
preoperative.cardiac_risk: ACC/AHA guidelines, but don't delay symptomatic CEA for cardiac workup
preoperative.antiplatelet: Continue aspirin, consider adding clopidogrel perioperatively

shunting.indications: Stump pressure <40-50 mmHg, EEG changes, contralateral occlusion

postoperative.monitoring: Neurological checks q1h initially, blood pressure control

complications.hematoma: 3-5% - may require emergent re-exploration if airway compromise
complications.hyperperfusion: Rare - severe headache, seizure, ICH after revascularization

definition.@value: Surgical removal of atherosclerotic plaque from carotid bifurcation for stroke prevention

clinical_pearls: Patch closure reduces restenosis compared to primary closure
Selective shunting based on monitoring is most common approach
Most cranial nerve injuries are transient - reassure patients

medicalCode.description: Extirpation of matter from right common carotid artery, open approach
